project_name: The gut microbiota has been typically viewed as an environmental factor for human health. Twins are well suited for investigating the concordance of their gut microbiomes and decomposing genetic and environmental influences. However, existing twin studies utilizing metagenomic shotgun sequencing have included only a few samples. Here, we sequenced fecal samples from 250 adult twins in the TwinsUK registry and constructed a comprehensive gut microbial reference gene catalog. We demonstrate heritability of many microbial taxa and functional modules in the gut microbiome, including those associated with diseases. Moreover, we identified 8 million SNPs in the gut microbiome and observe a high similarity in microbiome SNPs between twins that slowly decreases after decades of living apart. The results shed new light on the genetic and environmental influences on the composition and function of the gut microbiome that could relate to risk of complex diseases.

project_name: INSPIRE is a study of duodenal mucosal resurfacing, through intestinal ablation, to investigate its potential for treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus. In this study, the microbiome before and after intestinal ablation was studied in combination with a range of clinical markers.
taxonomic classification: The taxonomy of this Metagenome-Assembled Genome was originally computed with GTDBtk, which assigned the following taxonomic annotation: d__Bacteria;p__Proteobacteria;c__Gammaproteobacteria;o__Enterobacterales;f__Hafniaceae;g__Hafnia;s__Hafnia paralvei

project_name: Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is an effective therapy for recurrent Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI). However, the overall mechanisms of FMT have not been comprehensively elucidated, and the safety of FMT has recently become a serious concern because of the occurrence of drug-resistant bacteremia transmitted by FMT. We investigated whether the functional restoration of the bacteriomes and viromes by FMT could be an indicator of successful FMT.

project_name: Parkinson's disease has been improved to association with gastrointestinal symptoms and gut microbiota disorders, probiotics is considered as a technique for GI symptoms, while the regulative effect of probiotics on Parkinson's disease is limited. The supplementary treatment of Probio-M8 on Parkinson has been investigation.
